close_symbols: bool / stdbool.h (boolean type definition or project boolean typedef)
explanation:
- lfs_fs_desuperblock (declaration/prototype): The prototype can include compiler-specific extensions (e.g. __attribute__, calling-convention keywords, nonstandard qualifiers). Inspecting the declaration shows whether any language extensions are used in the called function signatures.
- lfs_fs_demove (declaration/prototype): Same reason as above — attributes or nonstandard parameter/return types in the prototype would be a language extension even though only called here.
- lfs_fs_deorphan (declaration/prototype): This call passes a boolean literal (true). The prototype reveals the parameter type (e.g. C99 bool, a project typedef, or some extension) and may itself contain attributes/extensions.
- lfs_t (typedef / struct definition): The target function uses lfs_t *lfs. The definition of lfs_t may employ compiler extensions (packed/aligned attributes, unnamed bit‑fields, compiler-specific type qualifiers) that would violate the MISRA rule.
- true (macro/identifier definition): The source uses the identifier true. You must determine whether true comes from standard stdbool.h, a project macro, or some nonstandard extension — only a definition check can confirm compliance.
- bool / stdbool.h (boolean type definition or project boolean typedef): If the callee or code relies on C99 _Bool/stdbool.h or a project typedef for boolean, you need to confirm this is standard C (C99) usage and not a compiler extension or nonstandard replacement.

These symbols are sufficient to determine whether the target function itself or the declarations/types it uses introduce any language extensions (attributes, nonstandard keywords, or nonportable typedefs/macros) that would violate the MISRA rule.
